document_title: Gastric (stomach) bleeding: Causes, symptoms and prevention
subsection_content:
Symptoms of stomach bleeding may or may not be obvious. Specific signs will depend on the speed and location of bleeding in the digestive tract (mouth, anus, etc.).
1. Epigastric abdominal pain
Stomach bleeding due to damaged mucosa will cause pain in the epigastric area that can spread to the back. These are all dangerous signs that need to be recognized for timely emergency treatment.
2. Changes in skin pigmentation or pale mucous membranes
Stomach bleeding is a dangerous complication of stomach diseases such as ulcers, cancer, infections... When the patient bleeds, it leads to blood loss, causing weakness, fatigue, and pale skin. and lack of vitality.
3. Nausea, vomiting blood
This is the most common and easily noticeable sign of stomach bleeding. Initially, the patient will feel full and bloated, then vomit food mixed with fresh or black blood. If the symptoms repeat continuously and a lot of blood is vomited, it will be very dangerous. In this case, the patient needs timely emergency treatment for monitoring.
4. Blood in stool
Diarrhea that is black in color like coffee grounds and has an unpleasant odor is a typical symptom of stomach bleeding. The larger the amount of stool and the darker the color, the more severe the condition. This symptom appears because blood from the stomach has mixed with food into the intestinal tract and out with waste. In addition, if the amount of bleeding is too much, it will cause defecation with bright red blood.
5. Signs of anemia
Continuous and prolonged stomach bleeding will cause the body to fall into a state of serious anemia. A series of easily noticeable signs such as dizziness, vertigo, dizziness, low blood pressure, fatigue, sweating... also known as hemorrhagic shock. In addition, when the stomach has problems, the patient will often feel anorexia and loss of appetite, thereby easily lacking nutrients and leading to weakness.
6. Fatigue, difficulty breathing
Stomach bleeding leads to anemia, which in turn causes a series of dangerous symptoms such as fatigue, difficulty breathing, shortness of breath and possible fainting. This is very dangerous, patients need to be examined promptly for immediate control.
